results.title: Just desserts
results.creator_credit: Monica Pellizzari and NRG Films Australia
results.brief_description: This delicious comedy about an Italo-Australian girl’s sexual awakening and her love for her mama’s cooking is written, produced and directed by Monica Pellizzari. Through the use of a split screen which separates the food from the experience, issues such as menstruation, masturbation, lesbianism and virginity are explored, against a backdrop of broth, venetian fritters, polenta, dumplings and pizza. Cast includes Dina Panozzo and Anne-Louise Lambert.

results.title: The Illustrated Auschwitz
results.creator_credit: Jackie Farkas, Lucia Salinas Briones and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The voice of an Auschwitz survivor (voice provided by Zsuzsi Weinstock) is presented against a backdrop of images, both hopeful and tragic. She speaks of her childhood impressions, of a belief that she couldn’t avoid her fate and the impact of Hitler’s voice. Footage from “The Wizard of Oz” is juxtaposed against images of haystacks and has a personal significance to the narrator who wished she could go ‘home’, but realises she has none to go to.

results.title: Workout
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Rhonda Small
results.brief_description: An impressionistic study of the relationship between horse and rider during a work out. To compete in Olympic equestrian events young riders must practice daily, sharpening their own skill and that of their horses. Shows the world as it must appear to horse and rider on a foggy morning in the Australian bush.

results.title: Ablutions
results.brief_description: Ablutions is an interactive journey where the user controls the fate of a character in a world that consumes technology. Through exploring the narrative the user partakes in the experience of cleansing the self from everyday technology and its commodities; questioning the nature of our identity. By doing this, freedom is redefined. Once cleansed, the character recovers the lost items, discovering their meaning and importance.

results.title: Fly
results.brief_description:
Winner of the Digital Pictures Award for best short dance film/video
was ‘Fly’ (2002) by New Zealand choreographer/director Shona
McCullough. Shona’s film, with performances from Richard Cesan and
John Callan, is a poignant story, told in dance/sign language, about
a 15 year old boy who wants to escape and 54 year old man who must
learn to let go.

results.title: Just desserts
results.brief_description: This wonderfully sensuous short presents the rites of puberty as a menu of Italian favourites: a young girls first period occurs when she is stomping the grapes; gnocchi is forever to remind her of first having sex with a boy; burnt polenta is the taste of lesbian longing. A lovely remembrance of an Italo-Australian adolescence.

results.brief_description: Originally made as station IDs for an American TV network - but rejected. Wonder why? (Screened at MIAF, JUne 2001).

results.title: I Look up, I look down
results.brief_description: A body falls gracefully through the air, kilometres from the earth, seeming to hover between falling, then rising again in a fluid dance that suspends and evades gravity. This looping video installation playfully dispels any laws of science as the casually dressed skydiver that we see floating through the air never gets closer to the ground. Moving hypnotically around the camera the body disorients all sense of up and down until at one point it seems to float, buffeted by the air, toward a passing plane.

results.title: Private eye
results.creator_credit: Tasfilm Productions, Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Peter McKinley
results.brief_description:
This 1970 film demonstrates the importance of eye safety and shows various methods of protection. The film opens with a sequence in film noir style of a ‘private eye’ working a case, with this gimmick interspersed throughout the film. It shows industrial working scenarios and various examples of eye protection, including safety glasses and helmets with visors.

Produced by Tasfilm Productions for the Department of Labour and Industry, Tasmania, and presented by Protector Sureguard.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Two Girls and a Baby
results.creator_credit: Annamax Media, Penny Robins and Kelli Simpson
results.brief_description: An entertaining look at the IVF process from the point of view of a lesbian couple as they deal with sperm banks, relationships, baby clothes, and community resistance.
